recordings.loc: Little Solsbury Hill, Bath and North East Somerset, England
recordings.rmk:
I believe this is an example of female bird song from a Skylark. In 1963, Juan Delius, a PhD student under Niko Tinbergen, published observations of Skylarks in Ravenglass. In his 1963 paper "Das Verhalten der Feldlerche" (The Behaviour of the Skylark), he describes the female's song as quieter than the male's and "eintönig und abgehackt" (monotonous and fragmented). The song in the recording I made certainly appears fragmented into pieces and I would describe the repeated phrases as monotonous. I made the recording in the mist with an Olympus LS-12 and Sennheiser ME66. I saw the bird on the ground.

From 3:32 I heard a golden plovers approaching which proceeded to fly right past me. There were around 15 in total and made an unexpected spectacle! You can heard the Doppler effect in their wing beats as they fly past the microphone. 

EQ edited below 2000 Hz mainly to remove clicks but also to reduce the sound of distant road noise. 

Reference:

Das Verhalten der Feldlerche
Delius, Juan (1963) - Journal article
Published in: Zeitschrift für Tierpsychologie : Sonderdruck ; 20 (1963), 3. - pp. 297-348. - ISSN 0044-3573

recordings.loc: Le Pot, Bazoncourt, Moselle, Grand Est
Charmy Down, Bath and North East Somerset, England
recordings.rmk:
Skylarks singing on Charmy Down on an unseasonably warm morning. There are multiple birds singing at once including in display flights. 
There is some possible mimicry including chiffchaff at 2:13.6, meadow pipit song(?) at 2:25.9 and 4:39.8 and also meadow pipit call at 5:07.0, black-headed gull(?) at 2:34.6 and 2:37.5, swallow at 3:33.7 and buzzard at 4:25.7 and 5:38.7.

Recorded with an Olympus LS-12 and Sennheiser ME66 handheld. EQ adjusted to remove light wind noise, handling noise and the sound of distant traffic.
Swallow reference recording (XC343873).

You may find the time references do not accurately point to the actual referred times, as discussed in [Forum topic 25398](https://www.xeno-canto.org/forum/topic/25398).

recordings.loc: Little Solsbury Hill, Bath and North East Somerset, England
recordings.rmk:
Skylark calls and song recorded in the mist with an Olympus LS-12 and Sennheiser ME66. I could not tell for sure but I believe the singing bird was on the ground based on the direction of the sound.  

The song contains mimicry of buzzard at 2:02.35, 2:44.9, 3:04.75 and 3:22.75, pied wagtail at 2:10.45, meadow pipit at 2:11.75 and yellow wagtail at 3:23.8. There is an actual Meadow Pipit in the recording from 4:20 up to the end of the track. Pied wagtails were also present and feature in my recording a few minutes later, XC545178.

EQ edited below 2000 Hz to remove distant road and railway sounds and to reduce handling noise.

You may find the time references do not accurately point to the actual referred times, as discussed in [Forum topic 25398](https://www.xeno-canto.org/forum/topic/25398).

recordings.loc: Little Solsbury Hill, Bath and North East Somerset, England
recordings.rmk:
Skylark calls recorded in the mist with an Olympus LS-12 and Sennheiser ME66. 
EQ edited below 2500 Hz to remove distant road noise and a little handling noise.
Three birds singing in competition.

**Comments**: None.

**Recording modifications**: HPF 1000 Hz, 12 dB. Modified using Audacity. Recorded using Olympus LS-P1.

**Habitat (inc. vegetation and level)**: Arable field with stubble. Bird flying.

**Behaviour**: Recording started when bird was in ascending flight, at about 1/3 of the height attained. Continues until the bird has landed. Bird circling the field.

**Sex (with ID cues)**: None.

**Weather and other conditions**: Cloudy morning. 

**Comments on other birds**: Eurasian blue tit calling at the beginning of the recording. Carrion crow calling at 0:21, 2:14. Common pheasant calling at 0:30, 1:10, 1:35, 2:30, 2:45, 3:27. Western jackdaw calling at 1:14, 3:20 - 3:30, 3:50 - 4:15.

Was surprised by this big-ish Lark running around on an artificial grass sportsfield on the Wajima seaboard. I first thought it should be Short-toed Lark together with breeding Skylarks. But now i think it is Japanese Skylark together with probably Red-rumped Swallow?

hope to hear from you

regards,
Gerben
It is very likely that this is a Skylark, some birds flew less than half a minute before this call by and quicly after this call some other Skylarks followed.. I think it's an aberrant call..

recordings.loc: Flamborough, East Riding of Yorkshire, England
recordings.rmk:
The recording is not modificated whatsoever. 
Habitat: meadow near a cliff by the sea.
Behaviour: adult singing  when hovering.
Good weather, 14C.

For this recording I placed my Olympus OM11 on the ground close to a boulder where a Skylark occasionally sang. Luckily the trick worked and the bird flew down, landed and then began to sing from the rock. Unfortunately a car disturbed the songster when it had just reached full voice. After an exhilarating 30 seconds it was flushed and - alas - did not return to its terrestrial perch. Within the first second, a Meadow Pipit calls, followed by a Wren at 0:08. The Skylark flies on to the rock at 0:12, uttering a harsh note that serves as a flight call and is also in territorial fisticuffs.  At 0:17 the Full Monty outpouring commences but is ended prematurely within thirty seconds. I have faded the end of the song burst: I do not want to be reminded of the car!

As well as a rich  torrent of song, Skylark also has a variety of calls. In contrast to mellifluous singing, calls are short and clipped. Terms such as 'buzzy', 'rippling' and 'chirrupy' can, at times, be invoked to describe them. This recording features a double note, followed by a triple note. Such combinations are common, although a one-off rendition of either is equally typical. To my ear, the double note has a 'hump' in the middle: meaning that the first part of the couplet rises whereas the second part falls. You could write this as 'bee-bup'. When the double note becomes a triple note, the opening couplet remains constant and the third element is a repetition of the second (falling) note. Hence: 'bee-bupbup'. I can, in my brain, fit words to this metre. So, the double note suggests 'bea-ver' and the triple note 'beaverbrook'. I know, perhaps only I can relate to this comparison. However, just because a 'handle' is personal does not mean that it is of limited use. If the reminder 'works for you' then it is a winner.

An example of a Skylark impersonating a neighbour. The neighbour is Chough and more information, as well as the actual Chough call that presumably inspired the Skylark to mimic the sound, is contained at XC241888. Three mimicked notes are all within a one-second burst just after 0:03.

Calm weather is uncommon on Irish islands. Seldom does the wind die down. A puff of breeze can be every bit as ruinous as a soughing wind. When 23 April 2015 dawned as still as a roosting heron, I was keen to record Skylarks. Being aerial singers, their voice is normally buffeted by the gusty headwind in which they like to sing. Despite relative calm, the slumber of the North Atlantic's swell never fades. Hence the background rumble is the sound of the ocean.  A Chough passed overhead and called three times. It can be heard at 0:2, 0:06 and 0:09. Within a short time, the Chough call was mimicked by the Skylark. As is often the case with impersonations, the counterfeit version is delivered at a significantly lower volume. This is hardly surprising if the imitator (in this case Skylark) is much smaller than the sound's originator. Moreover, the gaps between the notes of the genuine call are not preserved by the impersonator. Therefore the Skylark's version of the Chough call includes three calls in under one second: XC241900. Skylarks often repeat phrases and examples of this occur at 0:44 (duration five seconds; the phrase sounds like a bar from ceilidh music), 0:50 (duration three seconds) and 1:08 (duration three seconds).

One of many Skylarks (such happy news) that fill the air over just about every corner of Inishbofin, Co. Galway. Here are 15 seconds of Skylark song; much nicer than Andy Warhol's famous quote that refers to 15 seconds of transient human fame.
ZOOM H2n, high pass filter
Nightfall, bird on the ground.
